then one should make a wish. Rely on the previous method for seven days and nights.
It will certainly be as wished. If the star does not appear immediately, it is said that it is not sought. The seven stars of the Northern Dipper are the essence of the sun, moon, and five planets.
The seven luminaries encompass the eight directions above, shining on the celestial gods, and below, directly on the human realm.
They are in charge of good and evil, and distribute misfortune and blessings.
The myriad spirits look up to it.
If there are people who can worship and make offerings, they will have longevity, blessings, and nobility.
Those who do not have faith and respect will have a short life span.
Therefore, the Book of Fortune and Fate says:
In the world, there is a god of fate who, every time it reaches the gengshen day,
goes up to the Heavenly Emperor to report the sins and evils of the masses.ğŸ”½Those with heavy sins will have their calculations penetrated,
while those with light sins will have their records removed.
The calculations and records are the master of life.
Therefore, the Tathagata, for the sake of the sentient beings in the Dharma-ending age who have little blessings, short lives, and die prematurely,
expounded this method of the One Syllable Peak Wheel King summoning the seven stars of the Northern Dipper for making offerings and homa.
For those who make offerings,
it causes their life stars to remove their death records and return them to the records of life.
If the kings of various countries make a mandala in their own palaces,
make offerings in accordance with the Dharma, and worship,
the Northern Dipper will rejoice and protect them.
They will dwell in the superior position for a long time and always experience peace and stability.
